documentType: Bureau of Prisons psychology services records
summary: This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, created shortly after his arrest in July 2019. It includes an initial intake screening, a risk of sexual abusiveness assessment, and multiple suicide risk assessments. The records detail his mental health evaluation, his denial of any mental health issues or suicidal ideation, and the institution's precautionary measures due to his high-profile status and sex offense charges. This document is a Bureau of Prisons psychological assessment and suicide risk evaluation for Jeffrey Epstein conducted on July 9, 2019, the day after a court proceeding. It details his mental status, denies any suicidal ideation, and assesses his risk as low. It includes notes from a follow-up clinical contact on July 10, 2019. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service notes from July 2019 detailing Jeffrey Epstein's mental health observations, complaints about his incarceration conditions, and the incident on July 23 where he was found with a string around his neck, leading to a suicide watch. The notes document his psychological state, his interactions with staff, and his claims about a cellmate. This document is a series of Bureau of Prisons clinical psychology reports detailing daily mental status evaluations of inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 25-30, 2019, while he was on psychological observation following an incident where he was found with marks on his neck. The reports document his complaints about prison conditions, his inability to recall how he sustained the neck injury, his denial of suicidal intent, and his focus on his legal case. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service reports and a memorandum concerning Jeffrey Epstein's mental health and disciplinary status while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York in July and August 2019. It includes competency evaluations, suicide risk assessments, clinical contacts, and a timeline of staff activities following Epstein's reported suicide.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The subject of all psychological evaluations. A 66-year-old male incarcerated at MCC-NY on federal sex trafficking charges, previously served time for soliciting prostitution. He denied any mental health history or current symptoms.

persons.name: Dr. Central Office
persons.context: A psychologist from the Bureau of Prisons Central Office who was consulted regarding inmate Epstein's risk factors for suicidality.

persons.name: Inmate Brown
persons.context: Mentioned in a context about denying familial history of suicide behaviors, likely a clerical error or reference to another inmate's record within the same template.

persons.name: M. PhD/Chief Psychologist
persons.context: The psychologist who conducted the suicide risk assessment and clinical interviews with Jeffrey Epstein on July 9 and 10, 2019. The name is partially redacted.

persons.name: Epstein's brother
persons.context: Mentioned by Epstein as his only family, though he states he does not have a relationship with him. This is noted as a static risk factor (lack of family connections).

persons.name: Epstein's attorney
persons.context: Epstein expresses confidence in his attorney, describes him as competent, and requests to meet with him. He is awaiting a bail hearing.

persons.name: IM MPsyD
persons.context: A psychologist who attempted to see Epstein for a follow-up and later conducted the suicide risk assessment on July 23, 2019.

persons.name: Ph.D.
persons.context: A psychologist who evaluated Epstein on July 24, 2019, stepped him down from suicide watch, and documented his account of the neck incident and issues with his cellmate.

persons.name: Dr.
persons.context: Referenced as the psychologist who conducted a prior suicide risk assessment on Epstein on July 9, 2019, noting his denial of mental health history.

persons.name: Operations Lt.
persons.context: Notified the on-call psychologist in the early morning of July 23, 2019, that Epstein was being placed on suicide watch.

persons.name: Captain
persons.context: Was notified by the assessing psychologist about Epstein's statement to staff that his cellmate tried to kill him; the Captain stated they were already aware.

persons.name: Lt.
persons.context: A staff member in the SHU who was informed of Epstein's concerns about not receiving phone calls, and who promised to ensure he received his initial SHU phone call.

persons.name: Nick
persons.context: Epstein asked to speak with his old cellmate 'Nick' to see if he could provide information about the incident that caused the marks on Epstein's neck.

persons.name: Columbo
persons.context: A nurse from Medical who saw Epstein for a complaint about his right arm being numb and hanging.

persons.name: Proto
persons.context: Referred inmate Epstein for a competency evaluation related to the disciplinary process.

persons.name: Ella
persons.context: Conducted a follow-up clinical contact session with inmate Epstein in SHU on August 8, 2019.

persons.name: Plourde
persons.context: Contacted the report's author on August 10, 2019, to report that Mr. Epstein had committed suicide.

persons.name: Edge
persons.context: Spoken to on August 10, 2019, and asked the author to print and summarize BEMR/PDS notes following Epstein's suicide.

persons.name: Warden
persons.context: The Warden of MCC New York, who is the recipient of memoranda and whom staff met with multiple times following Epstein's suicide.

connections.description: Dr. Central Office was consulted by the assessing psychologist regarding Epstein's risk factors for suicidality.
No direct relationship described; Inmate Brown's name appears in what seems to be a template error within Epstein's record.
Epstein identifies his brother as his only family but states he does not have a relationship with him.
Epstein expresses confidence in his attorney, describes him as competent, and requests meetings with him regarding his legal case and bail hearing.
The psychologist conducted clinical interviews and suicide risk assessments with inmate Epstein on July 9 and 10, 2019.
Clinical therapeutic relationship; the psychologist provided interventions, psychoeducation, and addressed Epstein's complaints about prison conditions.
Clinical assessment relationship; the psychologist conducted the suicide risk assessment after the neck incident and documented conflicting statements from Epstein.
Clinical assessment and care relationship; the psychologist stepped Epstein down from suicide watch, provided hygiene items, and documented his fear of his cellmate.

Epstein reported his cellmate was 'agitated,' called him a 'pedophile,' and was reading a newspaper article about him. Epstein also told inmate companions his cellmate tried to kill him, though later claimed no memory of the neck incident.
Epstein was previously housed with Nick and wanted to speak to him to potentially trigger his memory about the neck injury incident.
Nurse Columbo provided medical evaluation for Epstein's complaint of numbness in his arm.
Psychologist M conducted multiple clinical evaluations and suicide risk assessments for inmate Epstein.
Unit Manager Proto referred Epstein for a psychological competency evaluation.
Chief Psychologist Ella conducted a follow-up clinical session with Epstein in SHU.
Epstein reported that his lawyers are emotionally supportive, visit him often, and he spends days with them in the attorney conference room.

events.title: Epstein's Initial BOP Intake and Court Proceeding
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein underwent initial psychological intake screening and a risk of sexual abusiveness assessment at MCC-NY. He also attended a court proceeding that day, the outcome of which prompted a suicide risk consultation.

events.title: Placement on Psychological Observation
events.description: Upon returning from court in the evening, Epstein was placed on a precautionary psychological observation status due to identified risk factors for suicidality, though he denied any suicidal ideation.

events.title: Formal Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: A psychologist conducted a formal suicide risk assessment on Epstein in the morning. He was found to have a low acute risk and absent chronic risk, with protective factors outweighing risk factors.

events.title: Previous Incarceration in Palm Beach
events.description: Epstein reported to BOP staff that he had previously served time in Palm Beach County jail on charges of soliciting prostitution.

events.title: Epstein's Court Proceeding
events.description: Epstein returned from a court proceeding in the evening. The assessment notes it 'may have given him bad news regarding his legal situation,' leading to his placement on precautionary psychological observation.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: A formal suicide risk assessment is conducted on Jeffrey Epstein by the chief psychologist. He is found to have a low acute suicide risk and no chronic risk.

events.title: Psychological Observation Contact
events.description: A follow-up clinical contact with Epstein where he expresses various concerns about housing, medical issues, and legal visits. He is found psychologically stable and is released from psychological observation.

events.title: Upcoming Bail Hearing
events.description: Epstein reports he is going to have a bail hearing on Monday (July 15, 2019) and believes he is going to be released from jail.

events.title: Epstein Found with String Around Neck
events.description: Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck in the early morning hours. This led to his placement on suicide watch and a subsequent suicide risk assessment.

events.title: Removal from Suicide Watch
events.description: After assessment, Epstein was stepped down from suicide watch to psychological observation. He adamantly denied suicidal intent, expressed fear of his former cellmate, and requested safer housing.

events.title: Placed in SHU Administrative Detention
events.description: Epstein was placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) under administrative detention status.

events.title: Series of Psychological Observations
events.description: Multiple psychology service notes document Epstein's complaints about prison conditions (cold, no property, no medication), his legal consultations, and his mental status, consistently denying suicidality until the neck incident.

events.title: Initial Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein is seen on psychological observation in the hospital area. He is in good spirits but cannot remember how he received marks around his neck. He complains about SHU conditions and denies suicidality.

events.title: Continued Observation and Medical Request
events.description: Epstein is seen again, smiling and joking. He continues to report no memory of the neck injury event and asks to speak to his old cellmate Nick. He complains of constipation and not having his Colace medication.

events.title: Reports of Sleep Deprivation and Anxiety
events.description: Epstein states he had only slept about 30 minutes per night for 5 days prior to the incident due to noise in SHU. He is anxious about returning to SHU. He denies suicidal ideation, calling himself 'a coward'.

events.title: Complaint of Numbness and Noise Aversion
events.description: Epstein complains of numbness in his right arm and neck. He reports being severely agitated by a malfunctioning toilet that flushed for 45 minutes, comparing the noise aversion to traits of Autism. He is moved to a different cell.

events.title: CPAP Machine and Return to SHU Planned
events.description: Epstein suggests his memory impairment may be due to sleep apnea and is expecting his CPAP machine. He requests to stay in the hospital area but is told he will return to SHU the next day.

events.title: Discontinuation of Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein states he hasn't slept well without his CPAP. Psychological observation is discontinued. He is to be seen in follow-up and is to be housed with an appropriate cellmate in SHU.

events.title: Competency Evaluation Completed
events.description: Psychologist M determined inmate Epstein was COMPETENT to proceed with the disciplinary process related to the July 23 incident.

events.title: Epstein Court Hearing and Clinical Follow-up
events.description: Epstein reported going to court for a status hearing. He was seen for a clinical follow-up after being removed from Psychological Observation.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment After Marshals Form
events.description: A Suicide Risk Assessment was conducted after US Marshals had Epstein sign a form noting 'suicidal tendencies' upon his return from court. The incident report from July 23 was expunged.

events.title: Final Documented Clinical Session
events.description: Chief Psychologist Ella conducted a follow-up session with Epstein in SHU. He reported feeling okay, denied suicidal ideation, and expressed a desire to go to general population.

events.title: Report of Epstein's Suicide
events.description: Staff member Plourde contacted the report's author to report that Jeffrey Epstein had committed suicide. This triggered a series of institutional responses.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, New York (MCC NYM)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was assessed by BOP psychology upon intake in July 2019 and found to have no mental health diagnosis, no current symptoms, and no history of mental health treatment.

Epstein was identified as being at risk for sexual abusiveness in a correctional setting due to his history of prior sexual abuse perpetration in the community and prior violent offense convictions, but was judged to be at 'Low Risk of Abusiveness' at that facility.

BOP psychology placed Epstein on a precautionary psychological observation status due to risk factors for suicidality, including his high-profile case, sex offense charges, pre-trial status, and a recent court proceeding.

A formal suicide risk assessment on July 9, 2019, concluded Epstein's overall acute suicide risk was 'Low' and chronic risk was 'Absent', citing protective factors like future orientation and denial of suicidal ideation.
Epstein reported to BOP staff that he had a brother but was not close to him, and that he had a support system of friends and associates in the community.
On July 9, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was assessed by a BOP psychologist as having a 'Low' acute suicide risk and 'Absent' chronic suicide risk, despite having high-profile charges.
Epstein explicitly and adamantly denied any past or present suicidal ideation, intention, or plan during the assessment, stating he was future-oriented and committed to life.
Epstein was placed on precautionary psychological observation after returning from a court proceeding on July 8, 2019, due to risk factors like his high-profile case and possible bad legal news.
The assessment notes Epstein's only family is a brother with whom he has no relationship, and that he has a support system of friends and associates in the community.
During a follow-up on July 10, 2019, Epstein was found psychologically stable, released from observation, and scheduled to be housed in the 9S area with a cellmate.

On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, resulting in a suicide watch. The origin of the string was unclear, with Epstein claiming no memory of the event.

Epstein told inmate companions that his cellmate tried to kill him, a statement he did not repeat to the assessing psychologist. He later described his cellmate as 'agitated' and said the cellmate had called him a 'pedophile.'

Epstein consistently denied any suicidal ideation, intention, or plan throughout the documented period, both before and after the neck incident, stating he had 'lots to do' for his legal case and a 'wonderful life.'

The psychology notes detail numerous complaints from Epstein about his incarceration conditions, including lack of property, feeling cold, not receiving medication (Colace), insufficient water, and issues with his orange jumpsuit.
Epstein expressed fear for his safety if returned to his previous cellmate and claimed there were 'many MS-13 gang members' on his initial unit, prompting a request for safer housing.
Jeffrey Epstein was placed on psychological observation after being found with marks and a scab around his neck, an incident for which he repeatedly claimed to have no memory.
Epstein consistently denied any suicidal or self-harm ideation, stating he was 'too vested' in his legal case and wanted to 'go back to living my life'.
He expressed significant distress about conditions in the Special Housing Unit (SHU), citing noise, smells, feeling punished, and restrictions on phone calls and recreation.
Clinical staff noted Epstein was engaged in lengthy legal visits daily, was animated with his attorneys, and discussed business and investment strategies with inmate companions.
Psychological observation was discontinued on July 30, 2019, with a plan for him to return to the SHU with an appropriate cellmate and receive follow-up monitoring.

On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck; he claimed not to remember how it happened, and it was unclear if he or someone else placed it there.
A psychological evaluation on July 30, 2019, found Epstein competent to proceed with the disciplinary process for the July 23 incident (charged with tattooing/self-mutilation).

Multiple suicide risk assessments between July and August 2019 consistently noted Epstein denied suicidal ideation, had future plans, and was deemed not to require suicide watch, with protective factors overriding risk factors.

On August 1, 2019, US Marshals had Epstein sign a form noting 'suicidal tendencies,' leading to another precautionary risk assessment where Epstein seemed surprised and denied stating he was suicidal.
The document includes a staff timeline entry for August 10, 2019, stating 'Contacted by Mr. Plourde to report to the institution. Informed Mr. Epstein committed suicide.'
